slides.title: Welcome to HTML
slides.content:
# The Language of the Web üåê

**HTML** (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard markup language for creating web pages. It describes the **structure** of a web page.

## Why Learn HTML?
- üèóÔ∏è **Foundation** - Every website uses HTML
- üöÄ **Easy to Start** - Human-readable and logical
- ü§ù **Universal** - Works on all browsers and devices

> üí° **Fun Fact:** The first version of HTML was written by Tim Berners-Lee in 1993 and had only 18 tags!

slides.title: HTML Attributes
slides.content: # Attributes ‚öôÔ∏è Attributes provide **additional information** about HTML elements. - All HTML elements can have attributes - Attributes are always specified in the **start tag** - Attributes usually come in name/value pairs like: `name="value"` ```html_not This is a link ``` - `href` specifies the URL for a link - `src` specifies the path to an image source

slides.title: The id Attribute
slides.content:
# The 'id' Attribute üÜî The `id` attribute specifies a **unique** id for an HTML element. - The value of the id attribute must be unique within the HTML document. - It is used to point to a specific style declaration in a style sheet or by JavaScript. ```html

Hello World

```

slides.title: The class Attribute
slides.content:
# The 'class' Attribute üè´ The `class` attribute is used to specify a **group** of elements. - Multiple HTML elements can share the same class. - Useful for applying the same style to many elements. ```html

Something went wrong.

Please try again.

```

slides.title: The DOCTYPE
slides.content:
# <!DOCTYPE html> üìú

The `<!DOCTYPE>` declaration represents the document type, and helps browsers to display web pages correctly.

- It must only appear **once**, at the top of the page (before any HTML tags).
- It is **not case sensitive**.
- The correct declaration for HTML5 is simply:

```html_not
<!DOCTYPE html>
```

Older versions of HTML (like XHTML) had much longer, complex doctypes!

slides.title: The Head Section
slides.content:
# The <head> Element üß†

The `<head>` element is a container for metadata (data about data).

Common elements inside elements include:
- `<title>`: Defines the title shown in the browser tab
- `<style>`: Defines internal CSS
- `<meta>`: Character set, viewport settings, description
- `<link>`: Links to external resources (like CSS files)
- `<script>`: JavaScript code

```html
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>My Awesome Page</title>
</head>
```

slides.title: The Body Section
slides.content:
# The <body> Element üëï

The `<body>` element contains all the contents of an HTML document, such as:
- Headings
- Paragraphs
- Images
- Hyperlinks
- Tables
- Lists

> ‚ö†Ô∏è **Note:** There can be only **one** `<body>` element in an HTML document.
